headline.main: From Apples to Terrorism, Governments Try to Answer How Safe Is Safe Enough

byline.original: By E. J. DIONNE Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: For the last week, governments here and abroad have been grappling with one of the most basic and complicated questions that human beings face: what risks are worth taking?
docs.snippet: LEAD: For the last week, governments here and abroad have been grappling with one of the most basic and complicated questions that human beings face: what risks are worth taking?

headline.main: Taxes Fail to Cover Drinking's Costs, Study Finds

keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Taxes on cigarettes cover the costs imposed on society by smoking, but taxes on alcohol do not pay for the costs of drinking, a new study reports.
docs.snippet: LEAD: Taxes on cigarettes cover the costs imposed on society by smoking, but taxes on alcohol do not pay for the costs of drinking, a new study reports.

headline.main: Sex Education Found to Bring Few Changes

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Sex education in the classroom appears to have little or no effect on altering sexual activity, promoting the use of birth control or lowering teen-age pregnancy, according to a review of five studies.
docs.snippet: LEAD: Sex education in the classroom appears to have little or no effect on altering sexual activity, promoting the use of birth control or lowering teen-age pregnancy, according to a review of five studies.
